docs.snippet: While it is not quite as helpful as Apple's Siri personal assistant, Google has a voice-activated feature in its software that lets you search the Web by speaking your search terms out loud. Google Voice Search is available in its mobile apps for ...
docs.lead_paragraph: While it is not quite as helpful as Apple's Siri personal assistant, Google has a voice-activated feature in its software that lets you search the Web by speaking your search terms out loud. Google Voice Search is available in its mobile apps for the iPhone, BlackBerry and Nokia S60v3 mobile phones. Depending on which version of the software is installed on the phone, Android users have their own options, including the Google Search widget, the Voice Actions app for Android or other apps from the Android Market. Google has voice search built into its Chrome Web browser for Windows, Mac OS X and Linux systems. To use it, you need to have a working microphone attached to the computer. To start, just click the microphone icon in Chrome's search box and speak your keywords aloud. Google has more on Chrome's voice search here. In addition to cutting down on keystrokes, searching by voice also comes in handy when you are not sure how to spell the thing you seek.

headline.main: Tip of The Week

docs.abstract: Personal Tech Tip of the Week notes Google's voice-activated feature Google Voice Search in its mobile apps. (M)0

docs.lead_paragraph: The news and financial services giant Thomson Reuters announced a shakeup in its leadership late Thursday afternoon, Amy Chozick reported, replacing its chief executive, Thomas H. Glocer, after he had struggled to turn around the company in an increasingly competitive market. The Wall Street Journal put those declining fortunes starkly, quoting the projected 2011 breakdown of the $24 billion financial-data market by Burton-Taylor International Consulting: Thomson Reuters at 31.4 percent of the market, down from 37.4 percent in 2005; Bloomberg LP at 30.8 percent of the market, up from 25.1 percent in 2005.

docs.snippet: In Friday’s New York Times, Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton report that Google is developing a package delivery service geared toward near-instant gratification. The service would let people order items on the Web from nearby stores and recei...

headline.main: Daily Report: Google May Step on Amazon's Turf

docs.abstract:
In Friday’s New York Times, Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton report that Google is developing a package delivery service geared toward near-instant gratification. The service would let people order items on the Web from nearby stores and receive them within a day.

The service is the latest example of how the biggest tech companies — including Google, Apple and Amazon — are trying to branch out and, in the process, are blurring the lines between their core businesses. But Google’s biggest hurdle in becoming a commerce business that competes with companies like Amazon and Apple is collecting credit card numbers, which enables customers to make quick purchases.

The new Google service is not likely to be aimed at small local merchants, says the blog EcommerceBytes. “Like eBay, Google is focused on large enterprise accounts,” it says. “A Google shipping service would be much more about helping its large merchant customers than about Google operating a ‘marketplace.’”

The Wall Street Journal’s Digits blog offers some back story on the rivalry between Google and Amazon. It says that when Google first introduced its AdWords advertising program, which was designed for small businesses, Amazon bought ads against millions of search keywords. To get around Google limits on ad purchases, Apple employees opened dozens of AdWords accounts, Digits reports.

headline.main: India Asks Big Web Companies to Screen Content

docs.abstract: The government's telecommunications minister is meeting Monday with top local officials from Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and Facebook to ask them to block defamatory or disparaging content before it is published, the India Ink blog reports.

docs.snippet: The government's telecommunications minister is meeting Monday with top local officials from Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and Facebook to ask them to block defamatory or disparaging content before it is published, the India Ink blog reports....
docs.lead_paragraph: As part of the Indian government's continuing efforts to rein in disparaging and defamatory content on the Internet, the telecommunications minister is meeting on Monday with top local officials from Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and Facebook to ask the companies to prescreen user content from India, the India Ink blog is reporting. The representatives from these companies are expected to tell the minister that the demand is impossible to meet given the volume of content coming from India, and that they cannot be responsible for judging that content. In addition to its efforts to force online services to control what goes up on the Internet, or over wireless connections, the government plans to set up its own unit to monitor information posted on Web sites and social media sites, India Ink reports. Read more »

docs.snippet: In Monday’s New York Times, Somini Sengupta reports on the Khan Academy, a program of math and science lessons developed by Salman Khan that has become a YouTube hit, attracting up to 3.5 million viewers a month. This fall, at least 36 schools a...

headline.main: Daily Report: Online Learning, Through the Khan Academy

docs.abstract:
In Monday’s New York Times, Somini Sengupta reports on the Khan Academy, a program of math and science lessons developed by Salman Khan that has become a YouTube hit, attracting up to 3.5 million viewers a month. This fall, at least 36 schools across the country are using software to try out Mr. Khan’s lessons in the classroom, combining traditional teaching with computer-based lessons and exercises.

The classroom programs are subsidized by more than $16.5 million in donations from the likes of Bill Gates, Google, the Silicon Valley Community Foundation and the O’Sullivan Foundation.

Critics say the lessons are simply rote learning in high-tech dress. But the popularity of the programs on YouTube have inspired interest in Mr. Khan’s approach; professors at Stanford University have borrowed his methods to offer a free online class in artificial intelligence.

The piece on the Khan Academy is part of the Times series, Grading the Digital Schools, which looks at the intersection of education, technology and business as schools embrace digital learning.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of programmers, writers, accountants and other workers labor at home doing contract work for companies like Google, Hewlett-Packard and NBC. The computers they use contain software that takes snapshots of what they are doing six times an hour. The snooping occurs randomly, making it impossible for the computer user to game the system.

headline.main: Big Brother in the Home Office

docs.abstract: Tens of thousands of programmers, writers, accountants and other workers labor at home doing contract work for companies like Google, Hewlett-Packard and NBC. The computers they use contain software that takes snapshots of what they are doing six times an hour. The growing popularity of contract work at large companies means such practices are now commonplace.

docs.snippet: At the opening of a two-day conference on digital freedom in the Netherlands, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and other international leaders argued that countries and private businesses should fight increasing efforts to restrict access...

headline.main: Daily Report: Clinton Pushes for Internet Freedom

docs.abstract:
At the opening of a two-day conference on digital freedom in the Netherlands, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and other international leaders argued that countries and private businesses should fight increasing efforts to restrict access to the Internet by repressive governments and even some democratic ones, reported Steven Lee Myers and Heather Timmons in Friday’s New York Times.

“When ideas are blocked, information deleted, conversations stifled and people constrained in their choices, the Internet is diminished for all of us,” Mrs. Clinton said in her remarks at the conference, which is sponsored by Google and the Dutch government.

Mrs. Clinton and other leaders talked about ways in which autocratic countries have limited access to the Internet. But the article also discusses how some democratic countries have been trying to restrict access as well.

For example, in India, government officials has been meeting with executives from Facebook, Yahoo, Microsoft and Google to express concern about content on YouTube and other sites that they said maligned politicians and religious figures.

The conference is being streamed live.

YouTube, which is owned by Google, announced the deal on a company blog on Friday afternoon. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed.

docs.snippet: A ruling is expected in federal court as soon as next week on whether the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff's massive fraud can appeal a decision that would make it difficult to recover potentially hundreds of millions of dollars from t...
docs.lead_paragraph: A ruling is expected in federal court as soon as next week on whether the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff's massive fraud can appeal a decision that would make it difficult to recover potentially hundreds of millions of dollars from the owners of the Mets. The appeal must be approved by United States District Judge Jed S. Rakoff, who in September dismissed nine of the 11 counts filed by the trustee against the Mets' owners. At the time, he ruled that Irving H. Picard, the trustee, had to prove that Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, the Mets' owners, willfully turned a blind eye to indications of possible fraud in Madoff's operation during their years of investing with him. ''Willful blindness'' is a higher legal standard to meet than the one that Picard has argued for. The Mets' owners have denied being aware of any red flags about Madoff.

docs.snippet: The National Transportation Safety Board is urging states to ban drivers from using hands-free devices, including wireless headsets. The concern was heightened by increasingly powerful smartphones that people use to e-mail, watch movies and play g...

headline.main: Daily Report: Safety Board Urges Cellphone Ban for Drivers

docs.abstract:
The National Transportation Safety Board is urging states to ban drivers from using hands-free devices, including wireless headsets. The concern was heightened by increasingly powerful smartphones that people use to e-mail, watch movies and play games.

Matt Richtel, who wrote a series in The New York Times in 2009 on the danger of cellphone use while driving, reports that the agency based its recommendation on evidence from its investigation of numerous crashes in which electronic distraction was a major contributing factor.

He reports that many mobile phone companies dropped their opposition over the last decade to any restrictions on the use of phones in cars, and have joined calls to ban texting while driving. In a statement, CTIA, the cellular telephone industry trade group, said it deferred to states about whether to enforce such bans.

A complete ban on phone use by drivers would have enormous impact on many car makers that are offering integrated hands-free, voice-activated systems that allow drivers to talk and do other tasks, like calling up their phone directory.

The ban would be controversial, as evidenced by the 650 comments the article in The Times quickly accumulated. Some think the tech industry will fight it, while others thought it would hasten the push for driverless cars. A San Francisco reader who calls himself LongView wrote: “I live in Silicon Valley and swear I heard the whispers of the Big Boys at Google, Facebook, Yahoo, AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile and Ad nauseam conspiring on a strategy to debunk the pronouncement.”

docs.abstract: Google.org, the search company's struggling philanthropic arm, was revamped this year, and charitable grant-making was added. It gave away $115 million, $40 million of which went to its pet causes of math and science education; fighting slavery and trafficking; using technology to solve problems; and educating girls.

docs.snippet: Two Congressional bills take aim at Internet sites that offer pirated copies of movies, television shows and music, reports Edward Wyatt in Thursday’s New York Times. Most such sites operate overseas, but the legislation, with bipartisan support...

headline.main: Daily Report: Congress Considers Bills to Prevent Piracy

docs.abstract:
Two Congressional bills take aim at Internet sites that offer pirated copies of movies, television shows and music, reports Edward Wyatt in Thursday’s New York Times. Most such sites operate overseas, but the legislation, with bipartisan support, is directed at companies in this country — search engines like Google and Yahoo, payment sites like PayPal and ad servers — that help the sites stay in business.

The bills are highly controversial, with opposing sides lining up for battle. Silicon Valley companies, free-speech advocates and venture investors argue that the bills are too broad and endanger both Web sites and free speech. Google has hired at least 15 lobbying firms to fight the bills, while Mozilla has put a link to a petition opposing them on its Firefox browser home page. The Motion Picture Association of America and other business groups support them.

A House committee is to take up one of the bills, the Stop Online Piracy Act, on Thursday. Here is the bill’s text. And for just a taste of the lively debate over the issue, here is a stream of commentary on Twitter.

Most such sites operate overseas, but the legislation, with bipartisan support, is directed at companies in this country -- search engines like Google and Yahoo, payment sites like PayPal and ad servers -- that help the sites stay in business.

docs.snippet: Tech journalists are picking apart the latest bad news from Research in Motion, maker of BlackBerry phones. On Thursday the company said that a new line of smartphones that it hoped would turn around its flagging fortunes would not come to market ...

headline.main: Daily Report: Research in Motion's Endless Struggles

docs.abstract:
Tech journalists are picking apart the latest bad news from Research in Motion, maker of BlackBerry phones. On Thursday the company said that a new line of smartphones that it hoped would turn around its flagging fortunes would not come to market until late next year, Ian Austen reports.

A lot is riding on these phones because they will use an operating system known as BlackBerry 10, replacing the company’s older, aging software. They could be RIM’s last hope of reversing its fortunes, which have suffered as smartphones from Apple and devices running Google’s Android software have surged. The company also said that its third-quarter net income fell 71 percent as it chopped the price of its BlackBerry PlayBook tablet and covered the costs of a big service interruption.

Gizmodo says that the PlayBook, which has been met with a cold reception in the marketplace, is putting the whole company at risk: “It’s RIM’s Gilligan, albatross, and giant self-destruct button all rolled into one.” The tablet could be sucking up financial and personnel resources that the company needs to bolster its more viable products, according to Gizmodo.

Writing for PaidContent, Tom Krazit lays the blame on RIM’s co-chief executives, Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis. He says they “failed to give anyone a reason to think RIM will be a player in mobile during 2012 or to explain why they should still have their jobs.”

Research in Motion shares were set to open about 10 percent lower on Friday.

headline.main: Lumière | Paris All Deco'd Out

docs.snippet: Over the past year visual-art obsessives have been having a field day with the feature of the Google smart-phone app called Google Goggles, which allows a user to shoot a picture of something - a painting, a photograph, a poster - and in seconds s...
docs.lead_paragraph: Over the past year visual-art obsessives have been having a field day with the feature of the Google smart-phone app called Google Goggles, which allows a user to shoot a picture of something - a painting, a photograph, a poster - and in seconds see an identification of the image and a list of search results for more information about it. The app, which was introduced for Android phones in late 2009 and last year for the iPhone, has been getting much better recently at digging up the title, artist and art-historical provenance of the work that the phone camera is looking at. Part of the credit for that can go to holders of huge art-image databases like the J. Paul Getty Museum, which provided Google several months ago with access to several hundred images from its collection, becoming the first museum to do so.

headline.main: Met on Google Goggles

docs.abstract: Metropolitan Museum of Art says it has supplied more than 76,000 images of paintings, drawings, prints and photographs to Google Goggles, smart-phone app that allows user to shoot a picture of something, identify it and get list of search results for more information about it. (M)o

docs.snippet: Patent battles have engulfed the cellphone industry for years, reflecting the heated competition. An important ruling by a federal agency, United States International Trade Commission, on Monday is described as one of the most significant so far b...

headline.main: Daily Report: Apple's Victory in Patent Ruling Hits Google

docs.abstract:
Patent battles have engulfed the cellphone industry for years, reflecting the heated competition. An important ruling by a federal agency, United States International Trade Commission, on Monday is described as one of the most significant so far by Nick Wingfield of The New York Times. Apple won a partial victory over the manufacturer HTC that could force changes in how Google’s Android phones function.

At the heart of the disputes are the kind of small but convenient features that would cause many people to complain if they were not in their smartphones. For example, the case that was decided Monday involved the technology that lets you tap your finger once on the touch screen to call a phone number that is written inside an e-mail or text message. It also involves the technology that allows you to schedule a calendar appointment, again with a single tap of the finger, for a date mentioned in an e-mail.

It was an issue that Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s late chief executive, felt passionate about. He told his biographer that Google had improperly copied many of the iPhone’s innovations, and that he was going to “destroy Android, because it’s a stolen product.”

The ruling got wide coverage. Darrell Etherington of GigaOm noted that Samsung made changes to the Galaxy Tab 10.1N in Germany in order to comply with a patent ruling against it there. He said “it’s very possible HTC will find a workaround before the import ban is scheduled to take effect on April 19, 2012. But such a workaround could chip away at Android’s usability and create a more frustrating experience for users.”

Rik Myslewski at The Register concluded: “It’s unlikely that HTC is about to be forced out of the U.S. market anytime in the foreseeable future, but it’s equally unlikely that the end of the Apple-Android patent war is anywhere in sight.”

docs.abstract: United States International Trade Commission rules that a set of important features commonly found in smartphones are protected by an Apple patent, a decision that could force changes in how Google's Android phones function; ruling against Taiwan-based mobile phone maker HTC is one of the most significant in a growing array of closely watched patent battles being waged around the globe by the mobile phone industry.

docs.snippet: A federal agency ruled on Monday that a set of important features commonly found in smartphones are protected by an Apple patent, a decision that could force changes in how Google's Android phones function.     The ruling, by the United States Int...
docs.lead_paragraph: A federal agency ruled on Monday that a set of important features commonly found in smartphones are protected by an Apple patent, a decision that could force changes in how Google's Android phones function. The ruling, by the United States International Trade Commission, is one of the most significant so far in a growing array of closely watched patent battles being waged around the globe by nearly all of the major players in the mobile industry. These fights reflect the heated competition among the companies, especially as Android phones gain market share.

headline.main: U.S. Backs Apple In Patent Ruling That Hits Google

docs.abstract: United States International Trade Commission rules that a set of important features commonly found in smartphones are protected by an Apple patent, a decision that could force changes in how Google's Android phones function; ruling against Taiwan-based mobile phone maker HTC is one of the most significant in a growing array of closely watched patent battles being waged around the globe by the mobile phone industry. Photos (M)

docs.snippet: STOCK SLIDE Zynga, the online game company, which closed below its offering price on Friday, continued to slide on Monday. Shares of Zynga, which was co-founded by Mark Pincus, fell nearly 5 percent, closing at a little more than $9 a share, about...
docs.lead_paragraph: STOCK SLIDE Zynga, the online game company, which closed below its offering price on Friday, continued to slide on Monday. Shares of Zynga, which was co-founded by Mark Pincus, fell nearly 5 percent, closing at a little more than $9 a share, about 10 percent below its offering price. But there were winners in the I.P.O. Zynga's underwriters, led by Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, collected $32.5 million in fees for the offering, the largest for an American Internet company since Google's debut in 2004. EVELYN M. RUSLI

headline.main: DealBook Online

docs.abstract: Zynga stocks continue to slide, falling nearly 5 percent to close at a little more than $9 a share, following its recent IPO; civil securities fraud charges filed by the SEC against six former Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac executives signal an aggressive turn in the pursuit of cases tied to the subprime mortgage crisis; European Goldfields agrees to an all-stock takeover by Eldorado Gold valued at 2.5 billion Canadian dollars; Polymetal and Evraz become the first Russian companies to be included in the FTSE 100 share index in London. (M)

docs.snippet: In Thursday’s New York Times, Julie Scelfo writes about how Skype, an eight-year-old technology, is being used in new ways in growing numbers of American homes. The Darvick family of Birmingham, Mich., for example, celebrates what they call “S...

headline.main: Daily Report: New Uses for Skype

docs.abstract:
In Thursday’s New York Times, Julie Scelfo writes about how Skype, an eight-year-old technology, is being used in new ways in growing numbers of American homes. The Darvick family of Birmingham, Mich., for example, celebrates what they call “Skypanukkah,” to observe the Jewish holiday; with family members spread out in three different cities, they light the Hanukkah candles together through video chat.

The article points out that on average, 300 million minutes of Skype video calls are made a day worldwide, up about 900 percent from 2007, according to data provided by Skype. People use other popular software programs, like FaceTime and Google Chat, to make more calls.

Among the new uses for Skype discussed in the article: giving a baby shower, providing child care, opening Christmas presents.

docs.snippet: The Internet should no longer reflect a 1950s view of the world, with America making the rules, the Minister says....
docs.lead_paragraph: In recent months the Indian government held meetings with Internet intermediaries like Facebook and Google, and asked them to prescreen user content and remove things that might be incendiary or objectionable, inspiring an outpouring of complaint and a rebuff from these companies. On Dec. 15, the government appeared to step down from that position, telling these companies in a meeting that there would be no censorship of Internet content.

headline.main: Insurance Against Cyber Attacks Expected to Boom

docs.abstract: Despite high-profile cyber attacks at Sony, Google, Epsilon, RSA and others this year, only a third of companies surveyed by Advisen, a research group, say they have purchased a cyber insurance policy. Experts say that more companies will get policies in the coming year because of Security and Exchange Commission rules requiring companies to disclose cyber attacks and their costs to shareholders.

docs.snippet: Ever get to the end of a road trip and realize you were just a few miles away from the shoe of the world's tallest man but you missed it? Maybe not, but On the Way, a new online travel site for road trippers, was designed to help find such unusual...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ever get to the end of a road trip and realize you were just a few miles away from the shoe of the world's tallest man but you missed it? Maybe not, but On the Way, a new online travel site for road trippers, was designed to help find such unusual attractions. When you enter your start and destination, the program will populate a map of your route with restaurants, museums and less traditional tourist sites using programming interfaces like Google Places, Foursquare, Yelp and Lonely Planet's Points of Interest. It can help you find a Starbucks between New York and Washington, but it's better for local alternatives like Miss Shirley's Cafe in Baltimore.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ever get to the end of a road trip and realize you were just a few miles away from the shoe of the world's tallest man and you missed it? Maybe not, but On the Way, a new online travel site for road trippers, was designed to help find such unusual attractions. When you enter your start and destination, the program will populate a map of your route with restaurants, museums and less traditional tourist sites using programming interfaces like Google Places, Foursquare, Yelp and Lonely Planet's Points of Interest. It can help you find a Starbucks between New York and Washington, but it's better for local alternatives like Miss Shirley's Cafe in Baltimore (above). A link will take you to the venue's Foursquare or Yelp pages, where you can see reviews.

docs.snippet: As the year winds down and the rest of the Oscar-contending movies hit theaters, it may take extra effort to keep up with what is playing where (and when). For serious film buffs, the Flixster add-on for Google's Chrome browser pulls in a list of ...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the year winds down and the rest of the Oscar-contending movies hit theaters, it may take extra effort to keep up with what is playing where (and when). For serious film buffs, the Flixster add-on for Google's Chrome browser pulls in a list of all the latest releases, trailers, show times and theaters near your location, plus new movies arriving soon or on DVD. The add-on is available in the Google Chrome Web store. And for those who prefer a mobile option for getting their film information on the go, Flixster has a free app for most mobile phone platforms, including Android, Windows Phone, BlackBerry and iOS.

headline.main: Tip of The Week

docs.abstract: Personal Tech Tip of the Week on movie browser add-ons and apps. (M)
